title: Fitch Upgrades Yingda's IFS to 'A'; Outlook Stable
text:
Fitch Upgrades Yingda's IFS to 'A'; Outlook Stable

(The following statement was released by the rating agency) Fitch Ratings-Hong Kong-October 18: Fitch Ratings has upgraded Yingda Taihe Property Insurance Co., Ltd's (YDPIC) Insurer Financial Strength (IFS) Rating to 'A' (Strong) from 'A-' (Strong). The Outlook is Stable. Key Rating Drivers The rating upgrade reflects a sustainable improvement in the insurer's capital strength and stronger profitability. YDPIC has a strong capital buffer to support business growth and asset risk. The insurer's capitalisation rose following a CNY1.5 billion issuance of capital supplementary bonds in October 2018. Its capital score in the Fitch Prism Factor-Based Capital Model improved to 'Very Strong' by end-2018 from 'Adequate' at end-2017. Its comprehensive solvency ratio under the China Risk-Oriented Solvency System rose to 250.7% by end-2Q19 after improving to 220.9% as of 4Q18 from 154.1% in 4Q17. Fitch expects YDPIC's Prism score to be maintained at the 'Very Strong' level. Financial leverage was 22.3% at end-June 2019 and Fitch expects it to be in the low 20% range in the near term. YDPIC's profitability has risen, stemming from a better underwriting performance and stable investment income. Fitch expects the insurer to enhance its underwriting results, with growth in a profitable business acquired from its shareholder, State Grid Corporation of China (SGCC, A+/Stable), a state-owned electricity utility corporation, and lower reliance on the motor insurance business. Fitch expects margins in the motor line to remain under pressure amid heightened competition as a result of greater pricing liberalisation in the non-mandatory (commercial) motor insurance business. YDPIC's combined ratio improved to 96.5% in 2018 from 102.4% in 2017, averaging 99.3% during 2016-2018. Consequently, its return on equity stood at 14.5% in 2018 compared with 9.6% in 2017. The rating upgrade also considers YDPIC's 'Moderate' business profile compared with other non-life insurers in China. YDPIC has an adequate business franchise within the domestic non-life sector, alongside diversified distribution channels. Its business portfolio comprises mainly commercial property, which accounted for 42% of gross premiums written in 2018, followed by motor (40%), liability (12%) and engineering (3%). The insurer will continue to underwrite more non-motor risks and estimates approximately 54% of its non-motor premiums will be sourced from SGCC in 2019 (50% in 2018). The ranking results in Fitch scoring YDPIC's business profile at 'bbb+' under the agency's credit-factor scoring guidelines. These considerations give the insurer's IFS rating the benefit of a one-notch uplift from its Standalone Credit Profile because of its ownership by and business support from its ultimate parent, SGCC, which owns 99.43% of YDPIC through a portfolio of fully and majority-owned subsidiaries, including Yingda International Holdings Group Limited. Fitch believes SGCC is likely to provide support to the insurer in times of stress. The insurer's exposure to risky assets is limited, and Fitch expects it to remain manageable. Stocks, long-term equity investments, equity-type funds and investment plans represented 30.5% of its shareholders' equity at end-1H19, compared with 42.5% at end-2018. Fitch believes YDPIC's underwriting capacity and capital strength will continue to rely on reinsurance utilisation due to its dominant commercial property risk exposure. The insurer's catastrophe exposure is reasonably managed through an excess-of-loss treaty to mitigate underwriting volatility or large potential claims from catastrophes, which would weaken its capital base.

RATING SENSITIVITIES Upgrade rating sensitivities include: - A solidifying business profile, including an improvement in operating scale and competitive position, and maintenance of strong profitability such that its combined ratio is below 95%. - A Prism score that is well into the 'Very Strong' category or higher on a sustained basis Downgrade rating sensitivities include: - A significant change in the shareholding structure, with SGCC losing its controlling stake in YDPIC. - A deterioration in YDPIC's capitalisation, with its Prism score falling to the lower end of the 'Strong' level, or the regulatory solvency ratio falling below 200%. - Weakening profitability, with a combined ratio consistently above 103%. - A material increase in its catastrophe exposure in the absence of adequate reinsurance protection ESG Considerations YDPIC has an ESG Relevance Score of 4, considering its large commercial-property insurance portfolio, which is susceptible to earthquake and windstorm risk exposure in China. This has a negative impact on the credit profile, and is relevant to the rating in conjunction with other factors. For more information on our ESG Relevance Scores, visit www.fitchratings.com/esg.
